title: Dissipation-assisted preparation of topological boundary states
authors: Yi Peng, Chao Yang, Haiping Hu, and Yucheng Wang
abstract:
Robust states emerging at the boundaries of a system are an important
hallmark of topological matter. Here, using the Su-Schrieffer-Heeger model and
the Kitaev chain as examples, we study the impact of a type of experimentally
realizable bond dissipation on topological systems by calculating the
steady-state density matrix, and demonstrate that such dissipation applied near
the system boundary can assist in preparing topological edge states of the
parent Hamiltonian, irrespective of the initial state or filling. This effect
stems from the matching between the phase distribution encoded in the
topological edge states and the target state prepared through bond dissipation.
This work provides new insights into the preparation of topological edge
states, particularly in the context of Majorana zero modes.
